pull.title: Shared benchmark format for command line and CSV outputs
pull.body:
Fixes #680 
**Change:** Shared benchmark formats for command line and CSV outputs

_Before:_ (only some part of the `bench_internal` output is shown here)
```bash
scalar_add: min 0.0319us / avg 0.0334us / max 0.0417us
scalar_negate: min 0.0162us / avg 0.0162us / max 0.0162us
scalar_mul: min 0.123us / avg 0.124us / max 0.124us
scalar_split: min 0.580us / avg 0.582us / max 0.584us
scalar_inverse: min 6.28us / avg 6.28us / max 6.29us
scalar_inverse_var: min 4.63us / avg 4.65us / max 4.69us
```

_After:_
```bash
Benchmark                      Min(μs)        Avg(μs)        Max(μs)       
----------------------------------------------------------------------
scalar_add                     0.0190         0.0194         0.0225         
scalar_negate                  0.00947        0.00967        0.0109         
scalar_mul                     0.0741         0.0744         0.0761         
scalar_split                   0.344          0.347          0.368          
scalar_inverse                 3.81           3.82           3.84           
scalar_inverse_var             2.67           2.68           2.73 
```
**Edit:** This format is outdated. You can find the [new format](https://github.com/bitcoin-core/secp256k1/pull/989#issuecomment-946296544) in this thread below.

These are all my benchmark outputs: (after formatting)
- [bench_ecdh](https://pastebin.ubuntu.com/p/vXdN5GRDcq/)
- [bench_ecmult](https://pastebin.ubuntu.com/p/mY9Wf4Dr3P/)
- [bench_internal](https://pastebin.ubuntu.com/p/rwHV5qbMvy/)
- [bench_recover](https://pastebin.ubuntu.com/p/27B5d9WxbN/)
- [bench_schnorrsig](https://pastebin.ubuntu.com/p/8tjGG5pgXd/)
- [bench_sign](https://pastebin.ubuntu.com/p/g7bQC9Bkgz/)
- [bench_verify](https://pastebin.ubuntu.com/p/nfsMnGhws5)

**Edit:** These benchmark output files are outdated. You can find the [updated files](https://github.com/bitcoin-core/secp256k1/pull/989#issuecomment-946296544) in this thread below.

repo.name: secp256k1
repo.description: Optimized C library for EC operations on curve secp256k1

repo.name: secp256k1
repo.description: Optimized C library for EC operations on curve secp256k1

events.body: Thanks, that looks nice! Concept ACK

I think now the offset is somewhat broken. At least on my machine, the number are not exactly below headers:

```
Benchmark                      Min(us)         Avg(us)         Max(us)        
----------------------------------------------------------------------
ecdsa_sign                     40.9           41.0           41.3     
```

Also, can we make sure that the `.` is always in the same column? See for example the last line in the output of `bench_internal`. I think a simple solution is just to reserve 4 or 5 digits left of the `.`, which should be fine for most users. :)

> I think now the offset is somewhat broken. At least on my machine, the number are not exactly below headers:

I will look into this.

> Also, can we make sure that the `.` is always in the same column?

I didn't notice this issue. Thanks!
Currently, I simply left justified the output of [`print_number`](https://github.com/bitcoin-core/secp256k1/blob/master/src/bench.h#L25) function. I will read more about the fixed point arithmetic used here and get this done.

>  Currently, I simply left justified the output of [`print_number`](https://github.com/bitcoin-core/secp256k1/blob/master/src/bench.h#L25) function. I will read more about the fixed point arithmetic used here and get this done.

The arithmetic is a little bit strange admittedly. We really wanted to avoid floating point types in the entire library. But I think you simply need to have some parameter w for decimal places left of the decimal point and count that down in the `do` loop. If it's then greater than 0 after the loop, print w spaces.

I aligned the decimal points in the same column ([new bench_internal](https://pastebin.ubuntu.com/p/6J4VVySwJV/)), but this breaks the format since we are padding the integer part.

we could pad with `0` instead of space to maintain the format but that might make the value hard to read. (shown below)
```bash
Benchmark                     Min(us)        Avg(us)        Max(us)        
----------------------------------------------------------------------
scalar_add                    0000.0189      0000.0190      0000.0193     
scalar_negate                 0000.00947     0000.00948     0000.00949    
scalar_mul                    0000.0741      0000.0742      0000.0744     
scalar_split                  0000.344       0000.345       0000.348      
scalar_inverse                0003.80        0003.82        0003.88     
```
What do you suggest? Should we revert back to the old format or pad with `0`s?

> I aligned the decimal points in the same column ([new bench_internal](https://pastebin.ubuntu.com/p/6J4VVySwJV/)), but this breaks the format since we are padding the integer part.

I don't understand, why does it break the format?

```
Benchmark                 Min(us)        Avg(us)        Max(us)        
|-----30------------------|-----15-------|------15------|------15------|

```
This is how I divided the width for each column.
Now let's consider the `Min(us)` column. For aligning the decimal points I gave 5 width for the integer part and 10 width for the fractional part of the total 15 width available for `Min(us)`.
```
Min(us)
|--------15------|
0.678 (old format) -----> proper alignment
    0.678 (4 spaces before zero since the integer width is 5)  ---> not proper alignment
|--5-|----10-----|
```

Oh okay, I think that's not a big deal. It looks slightly off but you could move the column headers to the center of the column.

We could even go a step further and a commas as column separators, and remove/replace the `---` line.  Then you get file that at least LibreOffice can import correctly as CSV (it parses the numbers correctly if you don't select "Trim spaces"). Don't know about about Excel, that would be interesting to know.

```
Benchmark                     ,    Min(us)    ,    Avg(us)    ,    Max(us)        

scalar_add                    ,    0.0189     ,    0.0190     ,    0.0193     
scalar_negate                 ,    0.00947    ,    0.00948    ,    0.00949    
scalar_mul                    ,    0.0741     ,    0.0742     ,    0.0744     
scalar_split                  ,    0.344      ,    0.345      ,    0.348      
[...]
```

That would also solve #680. To be honest, that's we really need in practice. And I think this shared format is pragmatic and much simpler than having command-line options. Otherwise you run a benchmark for say 10 min and only then you figure you want it as CSV. And if people really want "better" CSV format, they can still strip spaces manually by piping the output to some almost trivial command.

I was planning to work on the command line CSV option after this.

> this shared format is pragmatic and much simpler than having command-line options.

Then, I will do this.

As you said, we could also mention the UNIX commands to get a better CSV format from this command line output (something like [this](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/27388136/send-the-unix-output-to-a-csv-file)) on the readme.

> As you said, we could also mention the UNIX commands to get a better CSV format from this command line output (something like [this](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/27388136/send-the-unix-output-to-a-csv-file)) on the readme.

Indeed, `./bench_foo | tr -d ' '` will do. Even if we don't add commas as column separators, `./bench_foo | sed 's/ \{1,\}/,/g'` will add the commas... So that's another possibility.

Now the command line output looks like this:
```bash
Benchmark                     ,    Min(us)    ,    Avg(us)    ,    Max(us)    

scalar_add                    ,     0.0189    ,     0.0191    ,     0.0204    
scalar_negate                 ,     0.00947   ,     0.00948   ,     0.00949   
scalar_mul                    ,     0.0741    ,     0.0742    ,     0.0743    
scalar_split                  ,     0.344     ,     0.344     ,     0.346     
scalar_inverse                ,     3.80      ,     3.81      ,     3.87      
scalar_inverse_var            ,     2.67      ,     2.70      ,     2.94      
```
The command line output for all available benchmarks can be found [here](https://gist.github.com/siv2r/2452b57ba31373517006cb16849f908b).

This is the [CSV file](https://drive.google.com/file/d/1m8-ob0r1Rtaq3OyolpYqBv0MZusUArjO/view?usp=sharing) from the command line output for `bench_internal`.

_csv file generation:_ `./bench_internal | sed 2d | tr -d ' ' > bench_internal.csv`

rename.to: Shared benchmark format for command line and CSV outputs

events.body: Thanks. I have a few remaining nits (sorry to bother you again!) but this looks really nice now!

events.message:
Shared benchmark format for command line and CSV outputs

1. add `print_output_table_header_row` func to print the table header for benchmark output
2. modify the following benchmarks to include the table header
    - bench_ecdh.c
    - bench_ecmult.c
    - bench_internal.c
    - bench_recover.c
    - bench_schnorrsig.c
    - bench_sign.c
    - bench_verify.c
create csv file from the benchmark output

events.body:
> I have a few remaining nits (sorry to bother you again!)

No worries, I am learning a lot in this process. I have incorporated the new suggestions.

ACK b4b130678db31a7cabc2cde091bc4acbca92b7a3

Imports of the raw output (without sed) work fine with Google sheets. Thank you @siv2r.

comments.body:
```suggestion
    printf("%-30s %-15s %-15s %-15s\n", "Benchmark", "Min(us)", "Avg(us)", "Max(us)");
```

I think we should stick to ASCII chars here, otherwise the output depends on your local charset. (And the Unicode/wicechar support in C89 is pretty limited. We'd need `wprintf` but that's not in C89.)

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -100,6 +100,18 @@ To create a HTML report with coloured and annotated source code:
     $ mkdir -p coverage
     $ gcovr --exclude 'src/bench*' --html --html-details -o coverage/coverage.html
 
+Benchmark
+------------
+Binaries for benchmarking the libsecp256k1 functions will be present in the root directory after the build.
+
+To print the benchmark result to the command line:
+
+    $ ./bench_name
+
+To create a CSV file for the benchmark result :
+
+    $ ./bench_name | sed 2d | tr -d ' ' > bench_name.csv
comments.body:
```suggestion
    $ ./bench_name | sed '2d;s/ \{1,\}//g' > bench_name.csv
```

If we anyway rely on `sed` this does not need `tr`.

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -100,6 +100,18 @@ To create a HTML report with coloured and annotated source code:
     $ mkdir -p coverage
     $ gcovr --exclude 'src/bench*' --html --html-details -o coverage/coverage.html
 
+Benchmark
+------------
+Binaries for benchmarking the libsecp256k1 functions will be present in the root directory after the build.
comments.body:
```suggestion
If configured with `--enable-benchmark` (which is the default), binaries for benchmarking the libsecp256k1 functions will be present in the root directory after the build.
```

```suggestion
    printf(", "); /* as a column delimiter */
```
I think that's easier to grasp if you haven't read the discussion in this PR.

I think it would be slightly nicer to move the `printf(", ")` and `printf("   ")` out of this function because conceptually they don't belong to `print_number`. This would also make it easier to avoid the three spaces at the end of the line (trailing whitespace)
